results.title: Bristol: British city
results.creator_credit: Mary Francis, Alexander Shaw and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: The people of Bristol tell of their city, long since called the Maritime Capital of the West of England; a city with whose history many pioneers, adventurers and navigators, and many great moral and spiritual leaders have been associated. With its bustling life and half a million citizens, the city’s efficiency is still symbolised by the old phrase “shipshape and Bristol fashion”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mary Francis, Alexander Shaw and World Wide Pictures

results.title: Bristol fashion
results.creator_credit: Eric Fullilove, Terry Ashwood and Associated British-Pathe
results.brief_description: The history and development of the Port of Bristol - the only major municipally owned port in Britain. Illustrates the facilities available in the city docks and at Avonmouth and Portishead, and discusses plans for the expansion of dock services. Sequences on the history of architecture of Bristol are interwoven.

results.title: Bridgit
results.brief_description: The 32 minute work by Scottish artist Charlotte Prodger won the 2018 Turner Prize, and explores themes of class, gender, sexuality and neolithic goddesses.

constellations_other.name: A handheld aesthetic
constellations_other.description: Looking at the use of handycams and other consumer level devices in moving image works.

results.title: Bridget Riley
results.creator_credit: David Thompson, Arts Council of Great Britain and Balfour Films
results.brief_description: A profile of artist, Bridget Riley. Explores the inspirations she draws from the visual experiences in nature and follows her into her studio where she organises and activates her paintings. Credits include A.A. Englander (photographer) and Roy Ayton (editor).

results.title: Brett Whiteley: Alchemy
results.brief_description: A study of the work, philosophy and artistic process of renowned Australian painter, Brett Whiteley, as he prepares for and then exhibits the extensive panel work, “Alchemy”. The program is also integrated with a discussion of the history and mythology of alchemy in the ancient world and of the practices and beliefs of alchemists which weaves, in an explanatory and complementary way, through the coverage of Whiteley as he paints and discusses his work. Whiteley’s sense of producing different languages in painting, of shifting away from Australian naturalism to seek a balance between the natural and the surreal, is evoked insightfully in the program through the extensive interviews and commentary from Whiteley himself, the view of the artist at work in his studio, and through the thread of the study of alchemy. Along with Whiteley’s comments on his personal philosophies, the focus of the discussion delves into his fascinations and experiences, expressed through the form of his paintings, in terms of the alchemist notion of transmutation, and the ideal of a journey towards bursting through the boundary to dreams. This is exemplified in the work “Alchemy”, where the mind on its meanders, an order lost in detail and an eye to the spiritual is presented in the form of a paneled mural. The program contains footage of the opening of the exhibition of this work with its reception analysed through interviews and sound bytes of Whiteley’s colleagues, friends and family, art critics and curators, providing a close to this meditative outline of Brett Whiteley’s artistic process from original concept to exhibition.

results.title: Breath of life
results.creator_credit: Arthur E Jenks and Queensland. Dept. of Education
results.brief_description: Demonstrates mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, with emphasis on four points of procedure. Shows how mouth-to-mouth resuscitation can be used effectively in cases of drowning, electric shock, and obstruction in the throat.
